Thousands of heat and hot water complaints from an address in the Bronx. City blames one woman.

It was a hot Tuesday afternoon on April 11 when an official from the Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) of New York City was visiting 2176 Tiebout Avenue in the Bronx for the second time that week. A tenant had complained about the lack of hot water in their apartment.

“It is always the same woman,” the official alleged.

2176 Tiebout Avenue is located in an apartment community that comprises three buildings. Each of them has a different address but the city records 311 complaints from any of the three buildings under 2176 Tiebout Avenue.

The apartment community has 60 apartments in total.

A third of all the 311 complaints related to heat and hot water from Bronx zip code 10457 were from this apartment community.

Every year since 2020, it has registered over 3,000 complaints.

The address is largely responsible for the outsized complaints recorded from zip code 10457, which has a large population density and its median income of $42,639 is lower than the median income of the Bronx ($43,011). An analysis of 311 service requests related to heat and hot water from 2020 to 2022, collected from NYC Open Data, shows that zip codes that have a lower median income tend to register higher complaints related to heat and hot water.

Heat and hot water complaints from Bronx zip code 10457 have been consistently high since 2020


Each dot represents one zip code in the Bronx. The chart shows the number of complaints per 100K residents. Bigger the dot, higher the population of the zip code.

Residents of 2176 Tiebout Avenue said that most people in the building are old or retired. A woman who lives on the ground floor of one of the three buildings said she often dials the City to complain about heat and hot water.

"I sometimes complain 20 times in a day," she said.

The woman did not wish to be named and the HPD official visiting the address claimed that she was the one who has been registering the complaints. The building superintendent alleged the same.

Complaints are usually anonymous, especially if they are made online. The official said that the City may be able to track phone numbers in some cases. That day, the complaint was made online. But he was sure that the woman had filed the complaint.

“I first went to her apartment since it is usually her complaining. But she also doesn’t open the door. We then have to check with any other tenant to close the complaint,” the official said. He did not wished to be named.

He checked with a tenant on the fourth floor of the building who said there was no issue with water and the complaint was closed.

The official informed that once the boiler is turned on, heating and hot water take the longest to reach the top-most floor of the building. The top floor of this building is the fourth floor.

A tenant on the third floor told this reporter that he has not been having problems related to heat and hot water. “It is fine today,” he said while adding that he did not face issues in the past winter.

Another woman who lived in a different building in the apartment community said, “The heating is fine but the hot water is sporadic.”

A myriad of factors can be responsible for complaints from certain addresses. A statistical anylysis showed that while the percentage of hispanic or latino population in a zip code is positively correlated with the number of complaints, this correlation was not prominent from a more granular lens, i.e, the tract level.

However, it is worth mentioning that census tract 38303 where 2176 Tiebout Avenue is located has a majority non-white population.

Racial makeup of Census tract 38303 show that it has a majority non-white population


Each dot represents one census tract in the Bronx. The chart shows the number of complaints per 10K residents. Most tracts in the Bronx have a majority of residents who are non-white.

A statistical model developed by New York University researchers in 2017 found that "socioeconomic status, household characteristics, and language proficiency have a non-trivial effect on the propensity to use 311 across the city."

But the absence of "ground truth" data makes it difficult to determine the exact reasons behind the complaints, as the NYC researchers also note in their paper. While 311 can be a good indicator what residents are complaining about, it is not a perfect measure of the City's problems.

The data for this project was gathered from NYC Open Data and U.S. Census Data. All the code for this story can be found on GitHub. The charts were made on ggplot2 and edited on Adobe Illustrator.
